Title:
Rate heterogeneity in six protein-coding genes from the
holoparasite Balanophora (Balanophoraceae) and other Santalales
taxa.
Keywords:
B-class genes; LFY; RPB2; mitochondrial matR; Substitution
rate; Phylogeny; Santalales; Parasitic plants.
Abstract:
 Background and Aims. The holoparasitic flowering plant
Balanophora displays extreme floral reduction and was previously found
to have enormous rate acceleration in nuclear 18S rDNA region. So far,
it remains unclear whether non-ribosomal, protein coding genes of
Balanophora also evolve in an accelerated fashion and whether the genes
with high substitution rates retain their functionality. To tackle these
issues, we sequenced six different genes from two Balanophora species
and examined their rate variation and expression patterns.  Methods.
Sequences including nuclear PI, euAP3, TM6, LFY, RPB2, and mitochondrial
matR were determined from two Balanophora species and compared with
selected hemiparasitic Santalales species and autotrophic core eudicots.
Gene expression was detected for the six protein-coding genes and the
expression patterns of the three B-class genes (PI, AP3 and TM6) were
further examined across different Balanophora laxiflora organs using
RT-PCR.  Key results. Balanophora mitochondrial matR is highly
accelerated in both nonsynonymous (dN) and synonymous (dS) substitution
rates, whereas the rate variation of nuclear genes LFY, PI, euAP3, TM6,
and RPB2 are less dramatic. Significant dS increases were detected in
Balanophora PI, TM6 RPB2 as well as dN accelerations in euAP3. All of
the protein-coding genes are expressed in inflorescences, indicative of
their functionality. PI is restrictively expressed in tepals, synandria,
and floral bracts, whereas AP3 and TM6 are widely expressed in both male
and female inflorescences.  Conclusions. Despite the observation that
rates of sequence evolution are generally higher in Balanophora than in
hemiparasitic Santalales species and autotrophic core eudicots, the five
nuclear protein-coding genes are functional and are evolving at a much
slower rate than 18S rDNA. The mechanism or mechanisms responsible for
rapid sequence evolution and concomitant rate acceleration for 18S rDNA
and matR are currently not well understood and require further study in
Balanophora and other holoparasites.
